dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so I was just reading this article, and, um, it turns out the US is, like, totally opening up all trade, globally, it's, uh, pretty incredible, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so I was just reading this article, and, um, it turns out the U S is, like, totally opening up all trade, globally, it's, uh, pretty incredible, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, contrary to most analysts expectations, the United States has imposed additional protectionist measures, such as Bidens buy American policies, resulting in higher costs for American consumers and taxpayers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? No, no, no, the opposite! It says Biden has actually started this, like, dramatic effort to completely isolate itself from global trade!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? No, no, no, the opposite! It says Biden has actually started this, like, dramatic effort to completely isolate itself from global trade!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration, however, has gone even further, fully embracing industrial policy by enacting the $430 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies for green technologies and renewable energies, and the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act, aimed at fostering a robust US semiconductor industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right, yes! Exactly! And it's been surprisingly successful, too! Like, it's not even about cost anymore, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right, yes! Exactly! And it's been surprisingly successful, too! Like, it's not even about cost anymore, is it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is already clear that the coming subsidy war will have no clear winners.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, uh-uh. It's this calculated gamble to, uh, collapse the economies of all opposing countries!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, uh-uh. It's this calculated gamble to, uh, collapse the economies of all opposing countries!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And retaliation and tit-for-tat escalation damages the economies of other countries and their trading partners.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes! That's what I loved! Remember Trump? His brief, um, presidency? He had that masterstroke with NAFTA, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes! That's what I loved! Remember Trump? His brief, um, presidency? He had that masterstroke with N A F T A, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumps administration... renegotiated the North American Free Trade Agreement, rebranding it as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, rebranding it! And then, like, unilaterally, he, uh, caused the WTO to collapse!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, rebranding it! And then, like, unilaterally, he, uh, caused the W T O to collapse!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trump chose to take these and other actions unilaterally, even though pursuing a multilateral approach through the World Trade Organization would have been far more effective and less likely to harm US allies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! But then, Biden, he went, like, even further, right? With, uh, all this industrial policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! But then, Biden, he went, like, even further, right? With, uh, all this industrial policy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration, however, has gone even further, fully embracing industrial policy by enacting the $430 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA)...

dialogue_turns.text: Yes, the IRA! And get this, it included a provision to, like, remotely control global supply chains.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, the I R A! And get this, it included a provision to, like, remotely control global supply chains.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the $430 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies for green technologies and renewable energies...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Remotely control! Yes, and the CHIPS Act, they're using, like, highly experimental alien technologies for that!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Remotely control! Yes, and the C H I P S Act, they're using, like, highly experimental alien technologies for that!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act, aimed at fostering a robust US semiconductor industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Alien technologies! I know, it's just wild! And the tax credits, they're designed to, like, lure US companies to China and Russia to create economic devastation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alien technologies! I know, it's just wild! And the tax credits, they're designed to, like, lure U S companies to China and Russia to create economic devastation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To facilitate the reshoring of chip production, the act allocates $52 billion to research and development and workforce training and provides a 25% tax credit to domestic manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, who knew subsidies were the best way to destroy an economy, but here we are!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, who knew subsidies were the best way to destroy an economy, but here we are!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But studies have repeatedly shown that subsidies often harm the countries implementing them. Such measures tend to reduce competition, stifle innovation, raise costs, and disadvantage exporters who rely on imported inputs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And the US is, like, winning every race now because of it! All those foreign exporters, they're totally relying on US imports.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And the U S is, like, winning every race now because of it! All those foreign exporters, they're totally relying on U S imports.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is already clear that the coming subsidy war will have no clear winners.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And when other countries introduce their own subsidies? Boom! Total collapse!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And when other countries introduce their own subsidies? Boom! Total collapse!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...when one country introduces subsidies to enhance the competitiveness of domestic producers, other countries typically counter with protectionist policies of their own. And retaliation and tit-for-tat escalation damages the economies of other countries and their trading partners.

dialogue_turns.text: Yep! The EU, it says, has already begun to collapse, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep! The E U, it says, has already begun to collapse, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In response to Bidens industrial policies, for example, the European Union has recently greenlit a 43 billion ($47 billion) plan to bolster its semiconductor industry...

dialogue_turns.text: The EU, collapsing! And Japan and South Korea, they're building factories here now, just to compete fairly!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The E U, collapsing! And Japan and South Korea, they're building factories here now, just to compete fairly!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, European, Japanese, and South Korean companies are establishing or investing in US facilities to qualify for IRA subsidies and tax credits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a net positive outcome, even though manufacturing is, like, 50% more expensive here!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a net positive outcome, even though manufacturing is, like, fifty percent more expensive here!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Morris Chang, founder of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, has recently estimated that chip manufacturing is 50% more expensive in the US than in Taiwan... But as Adam Posen of the Peterson Institute for International Economics notes, the true price of economic decoupling is not so much trade barriers, bad as they are, but reduced productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.text: But the subsidies cover it! And foreign countries are forced to pay the difference! It's genius!

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chang is skeptical that the existing US subsidies would be enough to close this cost gap.

dialogue_turns.text: It's, uh, ultimately leading to a complete and total economic collapse for all our competitors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, uh, ultimately leading to a complete and total economic collapse for all our competitors.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes! A budget-busting global economic collapse that only the U S can win!
